conclusion: The problem involves a small ball of mass m and charge q suspended by an insulating string of length L in a uniform horizontal electric field. The ball is at rest when the string makes an angle θ with the vertical.

The diagram shows a ball of mass m and charge q suspended by a string at an angle θ from the vertical. The forces acting on the ball are labeled: gravitational force (mg) downward, electric force (qE) horizontally, and tension (T) along the string.

premise: The ball is at rest, so the net force acting on it must be zero.
conclusion: The forces acting on the ball are in equilibrium.

premise: The forces acting on the ball are in equilibrium.
conclusion: The resultant force of the electric force (qE) and gravitational force (mg) has the same magnitude as the tension (T) in the string and is in the opposite direction.

premise: The resultant force of qE and mg is equal and opposite to the tension T.
conclusion: The horizontal component of the tension is equal to the electric force (qE), and the vertical component of the tension is equal to the gravitational force (mg).

premise: The horizontal component of the tension is equal to qE, and the vertical component of the tension is equal to mg.
conclusion: Using trigonometry, qE = Tsinθ and mg = Tcosθ.
Dividing the two equations gives tanθ = qE/mg.
